thread.title: Cool caverns: Go underground to escape the Texas heat
thread.title_full: Cool caverns: Go underground to escape the Texas heat | Dallas Morning News

author: BEVERLY BURMEIER
title: Cool caverns: Go underground to escape the Texas heat
text:
Summer heat got you down? Instead of looking for relief at a lake, river or beach, head underground.
More than 3,000 caves are scattered throughout Texas, including many that are wild or undeveloped. Some of these, like the cave in Colorado Bend State Park, can be toured with a guide. But for experiences everyone can enjoy, the best options are Texas’ popular “show” caves. Several boast a constant temperature of 72 degrees, and a couple are even cooler.
Natural Bridge Caverns Billed as Texas’ Largest Underground Adventure, Natural Bridge Caverns opened to the public in the 1960s. During the 90-minute Discovery Tour, visitors travel to a depth of 180 feet and walk along winding paths at a pleasant 72 degrees.
See ancient formations that are still growing, including stone monuments, colorful rocks and glistening crystals. Since 2008, guides have led tours to a second cavern discovered at the site that features special lighting to showcase rare and delicate formations.
For a daylong family excursion, check out the gardens, Canopy Ropes Challenge, four zip lines and mining activities. Located 30 minutes north of San Antonio near New Braunfels, Natural Bridge Caverns is open year-round.
Contact: naturalbridgecaverns.com
Longhorn Cavern Unlike other Texas caves, Longhorn was created by rivers surging through cracks and holes millions of years ago. Left behind are unusual rock formations, domed ceilings, sinkholes and sparkling crystals.
Fossils dating to the Ice Age have been discovered in this prehistoric place of shelter, and evidence suggests Comanches inhabited the cave at least 400 years ago. The Confederate army used bat guano from the cave to secretly manufacture gunpowder during the Civil War, and popular legends claim outlaws used the cave for a hideout.
The walking tour covers 1.25 miles round trip and takes about 90 minutes. On the Wild Cave Tour, you’ll crawl through tight spaces using a headlamp. Learn about unexplained happenings on the Paranormal Tour, or book up to three hours of photography time in the cave.
Located in Longhorn Cavern State Park near Burnet, the cave stays a cool 68 degrees.
Contact: longhorncaverns.com
Inner Space Cavern Hidden for more than 10,000 years, Inner Space Cavern was discovered in 1963 during construction of a highway. A drill suddenly broke through solid limestone, revealing an enormous cavern system. Located 20 miles north of Austin off Interstate 35 near Georgetown, it is one of the best-preserved caves in Texas.
Today visitors walk 69 feet below ground to view dramatic geological formations in large, eerie caverns. The Adventure Tour departs every 20 to 30 minutes, no reservation required. On the Hidden Passages Tour, follow a guide to an undeveloped trail in a newly opened section — flashlight provided — or become a true spelunker on the Wild Cave Tour through undeveloped sections.
Although humidity hovers around 98 percent, the constant 72-degree temperature makes the cave pleasant even on scorching days.
Contact: innerspacecavern.com
Cascade Caverns Cascade Caverns was among the first of the state’s show caves. It was first explored by Apaches in the 1700s. Rediscovered in the 1840s, the cavern wasn’t commercially operated until the early 1930s.
Tours leave throughout the day for a one-hour excursion into a living cavern with outstanding rock formations. Millions of drops of water sparkle on the Diamond Ceiling. Visualize a beautiful waterfall and a cool year-round temperature of 64 degrees.
Located near Boerne, 14 miles northwest of San Antonio, the 105-acre park has opened new trails among live oak and cedar trees where visitors can see ridges and valleys and exposed fossils from the ancient seabed.
Contact: cascadecaverns.com
Caverns of Sonora More than 90 percent of Sonora’s geological features are still forming, which make this national natural landmark one of the most actively growing caves in the world. Located 15 miles southwest of Sonora on Interstate 10, halfway between San Antonio and Big Bend National Park, it’s considered one of the world’s most beautiful caves.
With 98 percent humidity, the temperature in the 72-degree cave feels more like 85. Walk through almost 2 miles on the Crystal Palace Tour, taking 360 stairs to 155 feet underground. Adventure seekers can navigate like a real spelunker on the Discovery Challenge, a four-hour tour that requires rappelling 50 feet into Devil’s Pit.
The cave was discovered in the early 20th century when a dog chased a raccoon into the opening. Rediscovery and exploration began in 1955, with public tours starting in 1960. Because human impact in the caverns was noticeable by then, the site’s overseers hope to stop destruction and preserve the cavern.
Contact: cavernsofsonora.com
Wonder World Park Visitors have been touring the Balcones Fault Line Cave, the nation’s only earthquake-formed cave, for at least 112 years. Going deep underground, you’ll see geological devastation caused by an ancient earthquake. Guides share stories of past eras and point out prehistoric fossils encased in rock formations.
Wonder World is a Texas state historical site near San Marcos, 1 mile off I-35. Cave tours begin at the active fault line and include a wildlife park, anti-gravity house and observation tower. The cave, which stays at a comfortable 72 degrees, is open daily from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.
Contact: wonderworldpark.com
Cave Without a Name Located in the Hill Country, 12 miles from Boerne, this beautiful cavern is filled with formations such as stalactites, stalagmites, soda straws and cave drapery.
Tour six major rooms in 66-degree comfort. Easy walkways and lighting make this living cavern simple to navigate. Tours depart throughout the day and last about an hour, entering on a stairwell that spirals down the original sinkhole opening and ending beside a clear subterranean brook.
Contact: cavewithoutaname.com
Beverly Burmeier is an Austin-area freelance writer.
